title: Understanding the Problem
text: One use for the derivative is to analyze motion along a line. Let s(t) be a function giving the position of an object at time $$t$$. The velocity of the object at time $$t$$ is given by v(t) $$=$$ s'(t), the derivative of s(t). First, solve for s'(t).
speech: One use for the derivative is to analyze motion along a line. Let s(t) be a function giving the position of an object at time , t . The velocity of the object at time  t  is given by v(t) , is equal to  s'(t), the derivative of s(t). First, solve for s'(t).
pacedSpeech: One use for the derivative is to analyze motion along a line. Let s(t) be a function giving the position of an object at time  , t
. The velocity of the object at time   t
is given by v(t)  , is equal to
s'(t), the derivative of s(t). First, solve for s'(t).

title: Taking the Derivative of s(t)
speech:
v(t)  is equal to  s'(t)
s(t)  is equal to  , negative 16 t squared,  +  560 t 
s'(t)  is equal to   2 times negative 16 times, t raised to the 2 minus 1 power  +  560 
s'(t)  is equal to,   negative 32 t,  +  560
pacedSpeech: 2 times negative 16 times, t raised to the 2 minus 1 power

title: Substituting Time
text: Plug $$t$$ $$=$$ $$3$$ into s'(t) $$=$$ $$-32t$$ + $$560$$ to solve for the velocity (ft/ s**2) of the rocket $$3$$ seconds after being fired.
speech: Plug  t   is equal to,   3  into s'(t) , is equal to   negative 32 t,  +  560  to solve for the velocity (ft/ s**2) of the rocket  3  seconds after being fired.
pacedSpeech: to solve for the velocity (ft/ s**2) of the rocket   3

title: Final Calculations
text: s'(3) $$=$$ $$-32(3)$$ + $$560$$ $$=$$ $$-96$$ + $$560$$. What is the velocity (ft/ s**2) of the rocket $$3$$ seconds after being fired?
